title: If it is not bad to kill millions of cows, why is it bad to kill millions of humans? - Quora

response.answer_text: It isn’t necessarily bad to kill millions of people if they threaten your survival, liberty, or you way of life. It has been done many times with the approval of societies, nations, religions, etc. “Thou shalt not kill” has many qualifications and exceptions. It is not bad to kill millions of cows because humans have to eat something. The alternatives to eating cows are no improvement, even for cows. Cows would go extinct if they weren’t a human food source. The nauseating aspect of it is that there are almost 8 billion people, and several billion of them eat cows rather than something else. That’s a lot of mass commercial killing of cows. And, the handling of it can be one more nauseating aspect of too damned many humans. But, suppose we let the domestic cow go extinct and plant all the cow pastures in vegetables. What do we to do about all the birds, rodents, insects, and some mammals that will want to eat our vegetables? It would be very kind to share with them. And, the more we share, the more of them there will be. You wouldn’t want to end up having to kill a few million of them, would you? And, what would you do with all that meat, if you didn’t eat it? On the other hand, those cow pastures support a great deal of wildlife, in addition to being self sustaining, and providing other environmental benefits. Furthermore, many ranchers and farmers are learning ways to deal with livestock predators, other than trying to wipe out entire species. Face it. If you are a human you are, by nature and necessity, a killer. Something is going to die in order for you to live, one way or another. Be grateful that you are one of nature’s killers rather than one of it’s killees. But, humans can be humane, and minimize their killing to that which is expedient and necessary. If you want to feel realistic empathy for non-human animals, pity those that are being robbed of their real estate by expanding human populations. Those that are being starved because they are cut off from their food supply. Those that are being poisoned by human waste products. Those species that are going extinct because they no longer have a place to live and breed. Don’t waste much sympathy on a cow. A typical beef cow gets a couple years of a stress free, well fed and cared for, life before it is humanely euthanized. That probably beats the shit out of a typical wild animal’s life and death experience. If cows could be housebroken and taught not to step on children, perhaps we could make pets of them like dogs and cats. Unfortunately, they evolved as ungulates, prey animals (their natural reason for existence is to be a food source for other animals). They lost the riding and working competition to the horse. You can blame that on nature, or your God. There is nothing I can do about it except opt for chicken, or try not to overcook my steak. And, I feel about the same amount of guilt that I would probably feel about killing a human to prevent that human from killing me. I have not yet evolved past being a biological creature. I must eat and consequently the cow must die. I’m not going to feed the beast while I starve.

Well… it’s all about morality, isn’t it? Humans invent their own moralities. There is nothing immoral about eating a natural, normal diet… and humans eat cows. My ancestors have eaten meat as long as they have been human beings. Science has some pretty good evidence that human intelligence got a real boost when we began to use fire to cook food, and particularly meat, making it more digestible. So there is nothing immoral about eating meat, or killing, in order to keep yourself alive and healthy. It is the way the earth has evolved to work. So how about the morality in killing humans. Well… that is an invented morality too. There have been plenty of societies in the past that used humans for sacrificial purposes in religious practices. In some societies the victims were volunteers, and they were treated with respect and were even envied. Humans choose their moralities. I choose to eat cow because it is part of a healthy diet. I don’t kill humans because it is unnecessary and I have been brought up thinking it is wrong. But there are circumstances where I would see it as the best alternative. I don’t agonize over moralities. I don’t overcomplicate my life. I have enough to do.

It’s a moral distinction most of us have chosen to make. Cattle, chickens, pigs and fish got the shitty end of the stick, while horses, dogs, cats, and dolphins at the far better end of it (or so I’d argue), with human beings getting to hold the stick. You can call it arbitrary, and it is. So is the distinction between having sex with a 20-YO, and a 10-YO. Do you also protest THAT choice between what is good and what is bad? If you do, you’ll have to convince the vast majority of us, who are absolutely on-board with it.

‘Good’ and ‘Bad’ are moral judgements, which are subjective. So we think killing humans is bad because we choose to think it so. If we didn’t think it so, then we’d die out as an evolutionary dead end. So, if your conscience wants you to kill millions of humans, then go ahead, I’m personally not going to stop you. You’ll probably get stopped by other people who don’t want you to do that though.

You’ve obviously never worked with cattle. Cows are the stupidest animal on the planet. They deserve to die. Try looking at row after row of white faces in a feed lot for a couple of days. You’d think the same thing. I once saw a Steer impale itself on a broken rail gate just because it was too stupid to back up. All the way through. We had to put it down and turn it into dog food. The meat was no good after that.

Well you see, it is bad to kill millions of cows. And chickens, and sheep, and fish and anything living. But the norm for the entire earth is that cows are not sentient creatures, deserving attention. But they are, just a different kind of intelligence to humans, who are a species of apes, and therefore animals
Because people aren’t cows… we don!t alot the same value to the lives of cows as we do to people… same as we don’t to chickens, pigs, sheep, etc.
